skill.name: hypothesis-generation
skill.description: Generate testable hypotheses. Formulate from observations, design experiments, explore competing explanations, develop predictions, propose mechanisms, for scientific inquiry across domains.
skill.summary: Generate testable hypotheses. Formulate from observations, design experiments, explore competing exp...
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill with no executable code, network calls, or file system access. Contains only markdown guides, LaTeX templates, and JSON configuration files for hypothesis generation methodology.

content.value_statement: Research requires testable hypotheses grounded in evidence. This skill guides you through formulating hypotheses from observations, designing experiments to test them, exploring competing explanations, and developing specific predictions for scientific inquiry across domains.
actual_capabilities: Formulate testable hypotheses from observations and preliminary data
Design experiments with proper controls, sample sizes, and statistical approaches
Evaluate hypotheses against quality criteria including testability and falsifiability
Search scientific literature using PubMed and web strategies with proper citation management
Generate professional LaTeX hypothesis reports with color-coded sections
limitations: Does not access external databases or APIs for live data retrieval
Does not perform statistical calculations or data analysis
Does not generate or execute experimental protocols
Does not access user files or execute code

use_cases.title: Research Proposal Development
use_cases.description: Develop rigorous hypotheses and experimental designs for thesis proposals or grant applications with proper methodology.

use_cases.title: Experimental Planning
use_cases.description: Design controlled experiments with appropriate controls, sample sizes, and statistical analysis plans for laboratory studies.

use_cases.title: Hypothesis Documentation
use_cases.description: Create professional hypothesis reports using LaTeX templates with proper formatting, citations, and structured sections.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Hypothesis
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me develop a testable hypothesis for [phenomenon observation]. I have observed that [describe observation]. What scientific questions should I ask and what hypotheses could explain this?

prompt_templates.title: Literature Grounding
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to ground my hypothesis in existing literature. The phenomenon is [describe]. Help me search for relevant evidence using PubMed and web strategies. What key papers support or contradict different explanations?

prompt_templates.title: Experimental Design
prompt_templates.prompt: Design experiments to test these hypotheses: [list hypotheses]. For each hypothesis, specify the experimental approach, controls, sample size rationale, statistical methods, and potential confounds to address.

prompt_templates.title: Full Report
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a complete hypothesis report in LaTeX format for [phenomenon]. Include executive summary, 3-5 competing hypotheses with mechanistic explanations and evidence citations, testable predictions with falsification criteria, and quality assessment tables. Use the hypothesis_generation.sty style package with proper page breaks.

output_examples.input: Generate hypotheses for why certain plant species show increased growth near urban areas
output: **Hypothesis 1: Heat Island Effect** - Warmer microclimates accelerate metabolic processes in plants, leading to increased growth rates compared to rural counterparts.
**Hypothesis 2: Elevated CO2 Concentration** - Higher atmospheric CO2 levels in urban areas enhance photosynthesis through CO2 fertilization effect.
**Hypothesis 3: Nutrient Runoff Hypothesis** - Urban runoff containing fertilizers and organic matter provides additional nutrient input to urban soils.
**Hypothesis 4: Reduced Herbivory** - Lower herbivore pressure in urban environments due to fragmented habitats allows plants to allocate more resources to growth.
**Priority Experiment:** Common garden experiment comparing urban-origin and rural-origin plants grown in controlled settings with CO2 and temperature manipulation.

best_practices: Ground all hypotheses in existing literature with proper citations rather than generating speculative explanations in isolation
Ensure each hypothesis includes specific, measurable predictions with clear falsification criteria before testing
Use the LaTeX template with strategic page breaks to prevent content overflow in hypothesis boxes
anti_patterns: Generating hypotheses without first searching for relevant literature or examining existing evidence
Proposing unfalsifiable hypotheses that explain any possible outcome without testable predictions
Including excessive detail in main hypothesis boxes instead of moving comprehensive evidence to appendices

faq.question: Which Claude models work best with this skill?
faq.answer: Works with all Claude models including Claude Sonnet 4.5, Opus, and Haiku for hypothesis generation tasks.

faq.question: What is the maximum number of hypotheses to generate?
faq.answer: Generate 3-5 competing hypotheses. More than 5 dilutes focus and makes experimental design impractical.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with other research skills?
faq.answer: Yes, pair with scientific-schematics for diagrams, data-analysis for statistics, and literature-search skills for comprehensive evidence.

faq.question: Is my research data safe?
faq.answer: This skill only processes text prompts locally. No data is transmitted externally or stored beyond the conversation.

faq.question: Why does my LaTeX document overflow pages?
faq.content: Use \newpage before each hypothesis box and keep main text boxes under 0.6 pages. Move detailed content to appendices.

faq.question: How does this differ from general brainstorming?
faq.answer: This skill enforces scientific rigor with evidence-based evaluation, testability requirements, and experimental design standards.
